Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Optimization and Coordination Control of Demand Response for Enhancing the Secure and Economic Operation of Power Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract



The objective of this research is to explore novel demand response management models and robust solutions for both Aggregators of Retail Consumers and Independent System Operators, which enable demand response to become a resource for providing ancillary services and maintaining system security. The approach is to (1) establish an adaptive price-sensitive load forecasting model; (2) propose a risk-constrained stochastic demand response scheduling model for Aggregators of Retail Consumers; (3) construct a two-stage security-constrained stochastic scheduling model for Independent System Operators.


Intellectual Merit: The demand response integration will be analyzed and quantified for minimizing daily operating costs, satisfying hourly security constraints, and accommodating uncertainties. This project is of practical importance since demand response is being implemented worldwide, and consumers will have opportunities to make distinctive contributions to energy security and environmental improvements in power system operation. The project team is qualified to perform the study and the research and educational facilities at Clarkson and Illinois Institute of Technology are adequate.


Broader Impacts: This project has profound impacts with the increasing deployment of distributed generations and plug-in hybrid vehicles. The proposed integrated research and educational activities and the new course development on modern power system operation and control in smart grid will attract more students to seek careers in power engineering. Underrepresented students will be recruited to participate in various tasks of this research. This project will increase public awareness and understanding of the complexity of power system operation among ratepayers, regulators, politicians, utility executives, market participants, and electricity consumers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project is to explore novel demand response management models and robust solutions for both Aggregators of Retail Consumers and Independent System Operators, which enable demand response to become a resource for providing ancillary services and maintaining system security. Major research activities include: (1) establish an adaptive price-sensitive load forecasting model; (2) propose a risk-constrained stochastic demand response scheduling model for Aggregators of Retail Consumers; (3) construct a two-stage security-constrained stochastic scheduling model for Independent System Operators. The educational objective of this project is to engage students in power systems and smart grid related research activities and disseminate research results to academia and industry.

 Through the support of this project, the PI and his team have published 11 journal papers, 4 conference papers, and 5 invited talks for disseminating the research findings. Through the support of this project, the PI has also developed and offered four new graduate level courses at Clarkson University. These courses have been offered via distance learning, and have attracted a good number of off-campus students.

 The project team has investigated demand response capabilities of various electricity consumers, including residential and typical industry users, and explored their impacts on the secure and economic operation of power systems. Research findings have shown that effective demand response integration could introduce monetary and secure benefits to both consumers and power systems. Figures show that how the accurate price-sensitive load forecasting could be achieved, how price-sensitive loads are simulated, and how these DR load would impact the system load profile and locational marginal prices. It would help minimize daily operating costs, satisfy hourly security constraints, and accommodate various system uncertainties such as those introduced by high penetration renewables. Research findings from this project are of practical importance since demand response is being implemented worldwide, and consumers will have opportunities to make distinctive contributions to energy security and environmental improvements in power systems operation.

 Research findings from this project will have profound impacts on the increasing deployment of distributed generations and plug-in hybrid vehicles, as uncertainties introduced by these technologies could be effectively mitigated via the effective utilization of demand response resources. This NSF grant has supported two graduate students and two undergraduate students on various research activities of this project. Outcomes from the integrated research and educational activities of this project, including numerical publications and the four new courses developed at Clarkson University, would continue to attract more students to seek their careers in power engineering.
